results.abstract: More than 1,700 New Yorkers pay $500 to $1,500 a head to attend New Year's Eve party at Rose Center for Earth and Space of American Museum of Natural History, which encloses the rebuilt Hayden Planetarium, and have a preview of sky show presented by new $3.5 million Zeiss star projector; photo (M)

headline.main: At Planetarium, the Fanciest Ball Is Inside the Cosmic One

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: ROSE CENTER FOR EARTH AND SPACE

results.snippet: It was, at very long last, the night to party until it wasn't 1999. And then? It was time to party some more.     And so, more than 1,700 revelers were lured to the bash that New Yorkers couldn't not go to. Overcoming false alarms warning of Scud...
results.lead_paragraph: It was, at very long last, the night to party until it wasn't 1999. And then? It was time to party some more. And so, more than 1,700 revelers were lured to the bash that New Yorkers couldn't not go to. Overcoming false alarms warning of Scud missiles, millennial Manhattan-phobia and the urge to cocoon, they flocked to Central Park West last night to be the first to see the American Museum of Natural History's new $210 million planetarium.

results.snippet: Even if humankind hasn't traveled beyond Earth's moon, our television transmissions have. And somewhere in the far reaches of the galaxy some alien race may be settling down in front of a viewing module getting ready to enjoy the adventures of the...
results.lead_paragraph: Even if humankind hasn't traveled beyond Earth's moon, our television transmissions have. And somewhere in the far reaches of the galaxy some alien race may be settling down in front of a viewing module getting ready to enjoy the adventures of the Starship Enterprise, only to find -- to their green-skinned horror -- that ''Star Trek'' or some other favorite science-fiction series has been unceremoniously canceled because of low ratings. Avid fans of science fiction, no matter what planet they call home, are all too familiar with the cycle of excitement, confusion and despair that seems to occur whenever a new science fiction series begins. First there's the promise of an intriguing, risk-taking show. The viewers quickly become puzzled when the fledgling series, having failed to gain a mass audience, is shuttled through various time slots, pre-empted, postponed or tossed into the black hole known as ''permanent hiatus.''

results.abstract: Article on dearth of corporate sponsors for arts programs and organizations in southern New Jersey at time when region is experiencing rapid growth; photo (M)

headline.main: Seeking Corporate Support in a Region Light on Corporations

results.snippet: CHILDREN in the Haddonfield public schools are busy reading tales of outer space and listening to ''alien'' music. The activity is all part of an orchestral appreciation program sponsored by the Haddonfield Symphony in which lessons are related to...
results.lead_paragraph: CHILDREN in the Haddonfield public schools are busy reading tales of outer space and listening to ''alien'' music. The activity is all part of an orchestral appreciation program sponsored by the Haddonfield Symphony in which lessons are related to concerts, such as one in March at the South Jersey Performing Arts Center called, ''3-2-1 Blast Off!'' narrated by an astronaut. The music appreciation program is underwritten by two companies with offices in nearby Cherry Hill: Lockheed Martin Technology Services and Commerce Bank. Subaru of America, another corporate neighbor, will be starting similar programs in schools around the country where Subaru has offices.

results.abstract: More than 200 miles of Breton coast around Le Croisic has been splattered with thick crude oil from tanker Erika, which broke up in stormy seas in December; photo; map; oyster beds are poluted, salt beds could be ruined and hundreds of thousands of tourists may well look elsewhere this year, which would be financial disaster for community (M)

headline.main: Le Croisic Journal; Oil Spreads Gloom on Brittany Shore

results.snippet: Jerome Guiheneuf works for this little fishing village on the Brittany coast tending to its parks and gardens. But these days he can usually be found on the beach in a disposable white jumpsuit, which from a distance makes him look like an astronaut....
results.lead_paragraph: Jerome Guiheneuf works for this little fishing village on the Brittany coast tending to its parks and gardens. But these days he can usually be found on the beach in a disposable white jumpsuit, which from a distance makes him look like an astronaut. Up close the work he is doing, trying to scoop and scrape tons of gluey black oil off the sand and the rocks, has taken its toll. He is splattered with the stuff and it smells bad. He says there is nothing much to be done about it. He is out here with every municipal worker who can be spared: the electricians, the carpenters, the painters.

results.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-6 I.R.A. Balks at Disarming; Ulster Peace Plan in Doubt Gerry Adams, the president of Sinn Fein, ruled out the possibility that the I.R.A. would meet a Monday deadline for beginning to disarm, dashing expectations that the guerrilla force his party represents politically was ready to move on weapons. A1 Judge Orders Stop to 'Hoopla' The federal judge weighing the fate of Elian Gonzalez told lawyers representing the Cuban boy's Miami relatives to stop what he viewed as excesses in rallying public opinion. He also moved up the date for their response to a Justice Department filing, to Feb. 14 from Feb. 24. A4

results.abstract: Scientists say John Glenn endured the effects of spaceflight at age 77 as well as, if not better than, the younger astronauts who accompanied him on space shuttle mission in 1998; say results challenge the concept of the elderly being frail individuals; photo (M)

headline.main: Glenn Rated as A-O.K. After Spaceflight

results.snippet: John Glenn endured the effects of spaceflight as well as, if not better than, the younger astronauts who accompanied him on his nine-day space shuttle mission in 1998, scientists said today.    Reporting on the scientific outcome of the 10-day...
results.lead_paragraph: John Glenn endured the effects of spaceflight as well as, if not better than, the younger astronauts who accompanied him on his nine-day space shuttle mission in 1998, scientists said today. Reporting on the scientific outcome of the 10-day mission, which ended on Nov. 7, 1988, when the space shuttle Discovery landed at Cape Canaveral, Fla., the scientists said Mr. Glenn, then 77, responded as well as astronauts half his age. The flight made Mr. Glenn, who at the time was a senator from Ohio, the oldest person to travel through space.
